newsitem.title: UK: FOCUS-BSkyB boosted by Internet link-up report.
newsitem.headline: FOCUS-BSkyB boosted by Internet link-up report.

text.p: Shares in satellite broadcaster British Sky Broadcasting Group Plc rose sharply on Friday following reports on the company's aim to link its planned digitial TV services to the Internet.

BSkyB shares were up 18-1/2 pence to 575-1/2p by early afternoon after the Financial Times newspaper said the firm planned to offer fast access to the Internet global computer network via conventional television sets fitted with a decoder.
The service would be in addition to home banking, home shopping and other interactive services, the newspaper said.
Noone at BskyB was immediately available for comment.

BSkyB, 40 percent-owned by Rupert Murdoch's News Corp, has been the centre of a wave of market speculation as it prepares to launch digital satellite television next year and is rumoured to be talking to a number of partners about promoting and subsidising the start-up.
Digital technology allows a much greater amount of information to be beamed from satellites and could potentially open up many new applications for current communications and broadcasting systems.
On August 20, BSkyB chief executive Sam Chisholm said the firm was considering a link-up with British Telecommunications Plc to supply interactive services. "That is a possibility," he said.
Analysts said it was likely the company would seek to expand into these fast-growing and hi-tech areas.
"It is a logical extension of service considering the equipment and the band-width that they will have," said Robert Jolliffe, media analyst at ABN Amro Hoare Govett.
"They are probably about 18 months ahead (of the competition)," he added.

Dealers said the shares were also marked higher ahead of the company's shares trading ex-dividend on Monday. "There is a defensive mark-up, people are short of stock," one trader said. "Trade is pretty thin."
